original.devanagari:
सम्भूतिं च विनाशं च यस्तद्वेदोभयं सह ।
विनाशेन मृत्युं तीर्त्वा सम्भूत्यामृतमश्नुते ॥ १४ ॥
original.iast:
sambhūtiṃ ca vināśaṃ ca yas tad vedobhayaṃ saha |
vināśena mṛtyuṃ tīrtvā sambhūtyāmṛtam aśnute || 14 ||

translations.text: He who knows both sambhūti and vināśa together - having crossed death through vināśa, he attains immortality through sambhūti.
He who knows both sambhūti and destruction together - crosses death through destruction and attains immortality through sambhūti.

bhashya.sanskrit:
सम्भूतिं च विनाशं च यस्तद्वेदोभयं सह, विनाशेन, विनाशो धर्मो यस्य कार्यस्य स तेन धर्मिणा अभेदेनोच्यते 'विनाशः' इति । तेन तदुपासनेनानैश्वर्यमधर्मकामादिदोषजातं च मृत्युं तीर्त्वा, हिरण्यगर्भोपासनेन ह्यणिमादिप्राप्तिः फलम् , तेनानैश्वर्यादिमृत्युमतीत्य, असम्भूत्या अव्याकृतोपासनया अमृतं प्रकृतिलयलक्षणम् अश्नुते । 'सम्भूतिं च विनाशं च' इत्यत्रावर्णलोपेन निर्देशो द्रष्टव्यः, प्रकृतिलयफलश्रुत्यनुरोधात् ॥ 

 मानुषदैववित्तसाध्यं फलं शास्त्रलक्षणं प्रकृतिलयान्तम् ; एतावती संसारगतिः । अतः परं पूर्वोक्तम् 'आत्मैवाभूद्विजानतः' इति सर्वात्मभाव एव सर्वैषणासंन्यासज्ञाननिष्ठाफलम् । एवं द्विप्रकारः प्रवृत्तिनिवृत्तिलक्षणो वेदार्थोऽत्र प्रकाशितः । तत्र प्रवृत्तिलक्षणस्य वेदार्थस्य विधिप्रतिषेधलक्षणस्य कृत्स्नस्य प्रकाशने प्रवर्ग्यान्तं ब्राह्मणमुपयुक्तम् । निवृत्तिलक्षणस्य प्रकाशने अत ऊर्ध्वं बृहदारण्यकम् । तत्र निषेकादिश्मशानान्तं कर्म कुर्वन् जिजीविषेद्यो विद्यया सहापरब्रह्मविषयया, तदुक्तम् — 'विद्यां चाविद्यां च यस्तद्वेदोभयं सह । अविद्यया मृत्युं तीर्त्वा विद्ययामृतमश्नुते' (ई. उ. १) इति, तत्र सोऽधिकारी केन मार्गेणामृतत्वमश्नुते इत्युच्यते — 'तद्यत्तत्सत्यमसौ स आदित्यो य एष एतस्मिन्मण्डले पुरुषो यश्चायं दक्षिणेऽक्षन्पुरुषः' (बृ. उ. ५ । ५ । २) एतदुभयं सत्यं ब्रह्मोपासीनः यथोक्तकर्मकृच्च यः, सोऽन्तकाले प्राप्ते सत्यात्मानमात्मनः प्राप्तिद्वारं याचते —
keyPoints: Combination (samuccaya) of sambhūti and asambhūti meditation is appropriate
Vināśa is the quality (dharma) of the effect (kārya); used non-separately with its substrate
Through vināśa meditation, one crosses death consisting of lack of powers and defects
Death includes anaiśvarya (lack of lordship), adharma, kāma (desire) and other defects
Through Hiraṇyagarbha meditation, one attains aṇimā and other powers
Having crossed death of powerlessness through sambhūti, one attains amṛta
Amṛta characterized as prakṛti-laya through avyākṛta (Prakṛti) meditation
Textual note: 'asambhūti' understood through elision (avarṇa-lopa) in the verse
Consistent with śruti teaching prakṛti-laya as the fruit
bhashya.notes: This mantra parallels verse 11, prescribing the combination of sambhūti and vināśa/asambhūti meditations. Śaṅkara Bhagavadpāda explains that vināśa is a quality of the effect (kārya) and refers to asambhūti by implication. Through meditation on what has vināśa as its quality (i.e., asambhūti/Prakṛti), one crosses the death of powerlessness and defects. Then through sambhūti (Hiraṇyagarbha) meditation, one attains supernatural powers. Finally, through avyākṛta (Prakṛti) meditation, one reaches the relative immortality of prakṛti-laya. The commentary notes that 'asambhūti' should be understood through grammatical elision (avarṇa-lopa) where vināśa stands for that which has vināśa as its quality.

centralTeaching: One who understands that sambhūti and vināśa (asambhūti) should be practiced together achieves results in sequence: crossing death (powerlessness and defects) through vināśa meditation, then attaining relative immortality (prakṛti-laya) through continued practice including sambhūti meditation.

coreConcepts.definition: Destruction, perishability; quality (dharma) of the effect (kārya), used to indicate asambhūti through metonymy
Lack of lordship/power; one aspect of mṛtyu (death) to be crossed through meditation
Single person's goals; both meditations serve the sequential goals of one individual practitioner
Elision of letter/sound; grammatical explanation for how 'vināśa' stands for 'asambhūti'
The substrate/possessor of a quality; that which has a dharma (quality)

relatedVerses.note: Similar teaching using vidyā/avidyā - crossing death, attaining immortality
